title: January has been the wettest month in Portland in nearly 3 years
summary:
PORTLAND, Ore — It’s not your imagination, it’s been a wet January.
And our wettest month in nearly three years!
If you like stats, here are a few:PDX has recorded just one totally dry day this month (Jan. 20) and we’re not likely to register another (Friday is iffy).
The monthly rain tally at PDX (as of Monday) is 6.56 inches, making this our wettest month since March 2017 (7.26 inches).
Here’s a snapshot of Tuesday's weather headlines:It still looks wet, with on and off showers throughout the day.

title: Portland closes out January with its highest rain total in nearly 3 years
summary:
Portland has seen some rain in its time.
But this month, the city and surrounding areas had the highest rain totals since 2017.
David Bishop, a meteorologist with the National Weather Service’s Portland office, said that as of Jan. 30, the rain total in the Portland area was 7.39 inches.
The area last surpassed that number in March of 2017, with 7.62 inches of rain.
The weather service said on Jan. 29 that Portland had seen rainfall on all but one day of the month.

summary:

title: This month on track to be Portland’s rainiest in nearly 3 years
summary:
Many people like to participate in “dry January,” but Portland’s weather is doing no such thing.
This month is on track to be the city’s rainiest in nearly three years.
The National Weather Service reported that this month, Portland has seen 6.94 inches of rain.
That’s the most the city has seen in a single month since March of 2017, according to KGW News.
The weather service said on Monday night that the precipitation would likely change from steady rain to showers on Tuesday, but there was little chance of the rain stopping.

title: Portland School Calendar For 2020-21 Approved By Board
summary:
From Portland Public Schools:Posted January 27, 2020The 2020-21 school year in Portland Public Schools will start on Wednesday, Sept. 2, and end on Friday, June 11 (if weather allows).
The calendar for next school year was approved by the Board of Education at its meeting on Tuesday.
The final day for high school seniors will be Wednesday, June 2, with graduation ceremonies starting Sunday, June 6.
The Sept. 2 start places PPS between announced start dates for two neighboring districts: the Lake Oswego School District has announced an Aug. 31 start, the Beaverton School District a Sept. 8 first day.
The 2020-21 calendar has been reformatted to be easier to navigate, with weekend dates removed and a format and icons that are more user-friendly.

Analysis Have Been Cited Thousands Of Media Outlets Nationwide Including All The Major News Networks

summary:
The shift toward remote buying of distressed properties means that REO homes available via online auction are attracting more competitive bids.
Although buyers at foreclosure auction began pulling back on their purchases before the recession hit, the sales rate at foreclosure auction began skyrocketing in late 2008—even while retail home prices continued to drop by double-digit percentages.
By the end of 2009, the national foreclosure auction sales rate reached 20.3%, not far below its 22.2% pre-crash peak in Q3 2004.
Preliminary data from February and March show those months also on track to see strong year-over-year appreciation in average foreclosure sales price.
Most investors are also responsibly rehabbing the roughly 30% of homes that are purchased at foreclosure auction and then held as rentals.

title: Snow moon over Portland, Vancouver metro area this weekend
summary:
PORTLAND, Ore. — This weekend's full moon, the Snow Moon, should be big and bright over the Portland metro area, according to KGW Meteorologist Rod Hill.
"Native American tribes referred to the second full moon of each year as the Snow Moon because the moonlight typically reflected from fields of snow in the month of February," Hill explained.
When it hits its peak on Saturday night, at about 11:33 p.m., Hill says there's a good chance skies will clear.
If you get pictures of the Snow Moon, share them with us!
Although the Snow Moon's peak is Saturday night, Hill said the moon will still be bright and beautiful on Sunday, when the skies are even clearer.

title: Brutal February, but not much rain overall: Portland’s 2019 weather
summary:
PORTLAND, Ore. (KOIN) – It’s official: 365 days of weather has come to an end!
February’s brutal weather was followed by a reasonably dry and mild March, which went for spring in general.
We wrapped up the year at 26.67 inches of rain, which was the third driest year on record (dating back to 1940).
We fell short of the average rainfall for multiple months, but one of the heavy-hitting months was November, falling below the 5.63 inches average by over 4 inches.
That being said, we’ve seen at least 237 days of measurable rain in Portland.

title: 9 large metro police departments reported 'double-digit percentage jumps' in domestic violence 911 calls as more people shelter at home.
summary:
According to CNN, several US cities have already reported increases in domestic violence cases and calls to local hotlines.
CNN reported that nine of the 20 largest metropolitan police departments reported "double-digit percentage jumps" in domestic violence 911 calls or cases in March compared to last year or the January or February 2020.
"Domestic violence is rooted in power and control, and all of us are feeling a loss of power and control right now," Katie Ray-Jones, the CEO of the National Domestic Violence Hotline told CNN.
In France, the police reported a 30% increase in domestic violence across the country, last week.
"They can't reach out safely, because their perpetrator is sitting right next to them," Ray-Jones told CNN.

title: Far-right U.S. politicians label lockdowns anti-constitutional
summary:
SPOKANE, Wash. (AP) — In deeply conservative eastern Washington state, a prominent state lawmaker kicked out of his Republican Party caucus labels the coronavirus as a foreign bio-weapon, accuses Marxists of using the pandemic to advance totalitarianism and rails against lockdown restrictions imposed by the Democratic governor.
A California teleconference last week to consider sport fishing limits in rural areas unprepared to handle influxes of anglers descended into chaos — with callers branding state officials as “fascists” and declaring it was time to “make fishing great again.”Across the U.S., elected officials from Pennsylvania to Oklahoma suspicious of big government and outraged with orders to close churches, gun stores and other businesses deemed non-essential insist that the public health response is being used as an excuse to trample constitutional rights.
The shutdowns reinforce long-held beliefs by some that governments would eventually use a national emergency to limit civil liberties and the vitriol is particularly strong across the pine forests of eastern Washington state — where conservative Rep. Matt Shea is a co-founder of the Coalition of Western States, a loose federation of politicians suspicious of big government, plus militia supporters.
Its goal is to “stop unconstitutional actions against United States citizens,?
according to a December report into Shea’s activities paid for by the Washington state House issued just before his own caucus exiled him.

title: Portland’s new rental screening, security deposit rules are unconstitutional, landlords claim
summary:
A rental industry group and two landlords they represent sued the City of Portland Thursday to block new housing screening and security deposit rules from taking effect, claiming they’re unconstitutional.
The group said its members own 30,000 rental units in Portland alone.
Newcomb owns 19 rental units in Portland and Mason owns 62, according to the lawsuit.
The Portland City Attorney’s Office and Office of Commissioner Chloe Eudaly, who led the effort for the new regulations, declined to comment on the lawsuit Friday.
The Portland Housing Bureau has been offering free training for landlords on the ordinances.

title: Womxn’s March rallied in Downtown Portland
summary:
PORTLAND, Ore. (KOIN) — Demonstrators turned out by the thousands on Sunday as they hit the pavement in a show of unity, strength, and endurance for the annual Portland Womxn’s March.
“Today means the rise of women, empowering women, and me, as a mother, passing that on to my daughter,” said Julie Johnson, who was in Sunday’s crowd.
It’s really empowering to have these really strong women here in our community that are just coming together for such an amazing cause,” said Phoebe Langwell, another marcher.
The first Womxn’s March in Downtown Portland in 2017 was one of the largest political protests in Oregon history.
The Womxn’s March, billed as a family-friendly event, had a number of different sponsors, with fiscal sponsorship from the YWCA of Greater Portland.

This panorama photo from March 2019 shows the trees in Terry Schrunk Plaza in full bloom.Grant Butler“There were branches that were cut down (Tuesday morning), and I was like, well, maybe they’re trimming,” she said.
The plaza was completed in 1975, and named the following year for Terry Schrunk, the late Portland mayor who served from 1956 to 1972.

title: Portland's bidding wars are cooling: Homes sold above asking price hit a 3-year low
summary:

Across the country, the number of residential properties bought for above listing price fell to a three-year low in 2019 as the market returned to normal, according to the real estate database.
During Portland's overheated real estate market in 2016, 2017 and 2018, owners of modest, flippable homes could get almost double asking price.

title: Portland protesters gather over impeachment acquittal
summary:

title: Portland to put homeless in public buildings
summary:

title: Waterfront Blues Festival canceled for 2020, will return in 2021
summary:
Portland’s Waterfront Blues Festival, originally planned for July 2-5, is being canceled this year because of the coronavirus pandemic.

Here’s the full text of the message from organizers:It is with heavy hearts that we are announcing that the Waterfront Blues Festival will not take place in 2020.
Looking ahead, all purchased passes for 2020 will be honored for the 2021 festival (July 2-5, 2021).

summary:
Portland’s city-owned parking garages remain open and on-street parking enforcement crews are still patrolling despite Gov.

While parking enforcement officers are still pounding the pavement, Brady said they are not focusing on every scofflaw.
The city has some 4,000 parking spaces in multiple Smart Park garages around downtown and Northwest Portland.
The Southwest 1st Avenue and Jefferson Street garage is about 60% full, Brady said, but others have more parking availability.

A fireplace’s cantilevering concrete hearth fronts a red brick wall.
Glass panels and privacy-providing clerestory windows frame the garden to the sky, and allow filtered natural light inside.
The family room’s midcentury Barzilay Multispan Vertical Storage System wall unit is a spare, but effective way to display curated collectibles.

Kate Brown issued a ban on on-premises dining, Ricker announced that Southeast Portland’s Pok Pok, Northwest Portland’s Pok Pok NW and three locations of his fish sauce wing shack Pok Pok Wing would stay open for takeout and delivery.
Two affiliated restaurants, Southeast Portland’s Whiskey Soda Lounge and Northwest Portland’s Ping Yang Pow, closed immediately.

title: Rains drenched Portland in September, but the city still came up dry this ‘water year’

Despite all of that precipitation, the city still ended its official “water year” several inches below normal.
2019, and in Portland it rained 30.62 inches, which is more than 5 inches short of the average.
Portland’s 2017-18 water year also came up dry, with 30.03 inches of precipitation.

title: Sunday was the coldest September day on record in Portland
summary:
The wild weekend weather was highlighted with Sunday’s headline: The coldest September day on record for the Rose City!
Downtown Portland recorded a high temperature of 49 degrees, becoming the only September day in 145 years of recordkeeping to not reach 50 degrees.
In fact, the previous record for holding in the 40s early in the fall season was October 12, 1881.
The high temperature at Portland International Airport only reached 52 degrees, tying the coldest high temperature for the month of September, which was set back in 1948.
Another chapter of this chilly episode hit the Willamette Valley and Southwest Washington Monday morning, with the coldest temperatures thus far of the short fall season.

title: Portland school district criticizes release of video of coach disarming student
summary:
A Portland, Oregon, school district has criticized the release of video footage that shows a high school football coach disarming a suicidal student, then hugging and comforting the teen.
The surveillance video, first obtained by the CBS affiliate KOIN 6 News, shows the Parkrose high school football coach Keanon Lowe encountering Angel Granados-Diaz, then 18.
KOIN said on its website it had obtained the video from the Multnomah county district attorney’s office via a public records request.
“It is important to know we denied permission for this video,” the school district superintendent, Michael Lopes-Serrao, said in an email to the Guardian.
“The evidence he was at Parkrose high school to commit suicide is overwhelming,” said Adam Thayne, a defense attorney.

title: Portland rents are holding steady with two-bedroom units at $1,337 a month
summary:
The average year-over-year rent growth in Oregon and in the U.S. is 1.4%, said Olyvia Ruhlmann of Apartment List.
Currently, median rents in Portland are $1,337 a month for a two-bedroom unit, the least expensive within the metro, followed by Forest Grove ($1,450) and Vancouver, Washington ($1,680).
Portland’s median two-bedroom rent is above the national average of $1,191, but is more affordable than Seattle ($1,686), San Francisco ($3,120) and Los Angeles ($1,760).
Hillsboro, OR is the most city expensive within the metro, boasting a two-bedroom median of $2,098, and the fastest year-over-year growth at 3.7%.
Studio and two-bedroom units are typically listed for rent on Zillow for 22 days while a one bedroom lasts for 24 days.

summary:
PORTLAND, Ore. (KOIN) — The Oregon Department of Forestry and its partners worked to contain fires in rural forested areas as windy conditions and low humidity gripped the state.
Twenty-two fires were reported across the Willamette Valley in the last 24 hours, ODF said Wednesday.
Officials said most of the fires were likely caused by prescribed burns rekindled by the wind.
The Coos Forest Protective Association responded to four fires since Sunday, one of which the agency says was powerline related.
Fire officials reminded the public to be extra careful while the weather remains dry and windy.

title: Water filtration facility project comes with funding hurdle
summary:
The city of Portland is looking to take another step toward kick-starting a massive water filtration facility project by issuing bonds to finance a major portion of the work.
The WIFIA program allows for loans to be drawn out over time, and repayment to be deferred until five years after substantial completion – 2032, in the case of the Bull Run filtration facility, which by mandate must be in operation by 2027.
The City Council in November 2019 voted to proceed with a recommended option for the filtration facility that will treat 145 million gallons of water per day using ozone and conventional filtration.
The Bull Run watershed provides drinking water for over 650,000 Portlanders and 300,000 additional residents of other Portland-area municipalities that purchase water from the city.
The filtration facility has entered a two-year design phase, while planning for the pipelines is under way and will move to a design phase next year.

summary:

It took a solid 0.49 inches of rain since midnight to help push us out of that concern.
Our average for the month of November, which is typically our wettest month, is 5.63 inches.
For example, just from 4 a.m. to 5 a.m. this morning, we collected .25 inches of rain.

title: The Pacific Northwest Just Had One of Its Driest Novembers, and Cascades Snowpack is Suffering
summary:
At a Glance The Pacific Northwest has a wet reputation, but that hasn't been the case lately.
The Pacific Northwest just had one of its driest Novembers on record, in what is usually one of the wettest months of the year, and that has taken a toll on early-season snowpack in the Cascades.
When the Pacific Northwest is mentioned, wet weather might come to mind.
Seattle had its driest November since 1976, picking up only 1.71 inches of rain, just one-quarter of its average.
In November, the jet stream often diverted north of the Pacific Northwest, sparing it the typical soaking November storms.

title: Will this be the driest calendar year dating back to 2000?
summary:
As of mid-November, we’ve had five months at or above average and six months below average.
Since 2000, the annual minimum rain for a calendar year was 26.72 inches in 2013.
If we wrap this year up below that 26.72 inches total, it would be the driest calendar year since 2013 and the driest of the last 19 years.
That being said, 2018 finished at 27.30 inches, which was the third driest year since 2000.
However, we haven’t had two back-to-back years below 30 inches since 2000.

title: Joe Biden stops in Portland for fundraiser, talks foreign politics and Trump
summary:
In his latest stop on the campaign trail, former Vice President Joe Biden held a small private fundraiser in Portland on Saturday, gathering money and momentum to head into the 2020 presidential race.
Hosted by Tin House co-founder Win McCormack and Democratic political consultant Carol Butler, Butler introduced Biden to the crowd.
But Biden wove a common thread throughout his comments -- his condemnation of President Donald Trump’s leadership.
“This is the most corrupt president in modern American history, maybe in American history,” Biden said during his opening comments.
In Oregon, Biden’s campaign has so far reported raising less than $78,000 from 214 Oregonians, according to federal campaign filings.

title: Magnitude 4.5 earthquake hits Oregon coast
summary:
A small earthquake hit Port Orford on the Oregon coast Friday, shaking the community shortly after dusk.
The 4.5-magnitude earthquake struck at about 5:45 p.m., with its epicenter about two miles inland, according to the U.S. Geological Survey.
That differs from a recent string of earthquakes in October that struck far off the Oregon coast.
A magnitude-4.7 temblor struck 96 miles offshore from Port Orford on Oct. 17 – one of five that rattled the coast that month.
No damage was reported from the most recent earthquake, nor was there any threat of tsunami.

title: Introducing the Amsterdam City Doughnut
authors: Kate Raworth Is A Renegade Economist Focused On Exploring The Economic Mindset Needed To Address The Century S Social
Ecological Challenges. She Is A Senior Visiting Research Associate
Advisory Board Member At Oxford University S Environmental Change Institute
Teaches In Its Masters Program For Environmental Change
Management. She Is Also Senior Associate...
summary:
April 8 was the launch of the Amsterdam City Doughnut, which takes the global concept of the Doughnut and turns it into a tool for transformative action in the city of Amsterdam.
Amsterdam is a great place for launching this tool because this city has already placed the Doughnut at the heart of its long-term vision and policymaking, and is home to the Amsterdam Donut Coalition, a network of inspiring change-makers who are already putting the Doughnut into practice in their city.
To dive into these issues, we explore four interdependent questions, applied in this case to Amsterdam:These questions turn into the four ‘lenses’ of the City Doughnut, producing a new ‘portrait’ of the city from four inter-connected perspectives.
Everyone is likewise welcome to leave responses and suggestions about Amsterdam’s City Doughnut, and the City Doughnut tool, below in the Comments section of this blog.
I believe this newly downscaled Doughnut tool has a great deal to offer and I look forward to seeing it turned into transformative action, in Amsterdam and far beyond.

Thirty-five wineries from the Willamette Valley and the Columbia River Gorge poured 66 samples of their yet-to-be-released 2019 vintage alongside 90 samples from previous vintages.
Despite the challenges, winemakers were very optimistic about the future of the 2019 vintage.

title: Brutal February, but not much rain overall: Portland’s 2019 weather
summary:
PORTLAND, Ore. (KOIN) – It’s official: 365 days of weather has come to an end!
February’s brutal weather was followed by a reasonably dry and mild March, which went for spring in general.
We wrapped up the year at 26.67 inches of rain, which was the third driest year on record (dating back to 1940).
We fell short of the average rainfall for multiple months, but one of the heavy-hitting months was November, falling below the 5.63 inches average by over 4 inches.
That being said, we’ve seen at least 237 days of measurable rain in Portland.

title: Portland youth activists part of National Climate Strike
summary:
PORTLAND, Ore. (KOIN) — Young Portland activists joined a nationwide climate strike Friday to “demand real tangible action” to tackle the climate crisis.
Across the US, hundreds of thousands of people — youth and adults — marched through streets to bring attention to the issue and focus the attention of elected leaders.
In Portland, the Climate Strike began at 10:30 a.m. at Shemanski Park with a rally and speakers.
Details: Global Climate StrikeOrganizers have a permit for the street march.
Traffic in the area may be impacted and TriMet lines may be disrupted.

title: Oregon’s flu season on track to match last year as outbreaks increase more than 300% in a week
summary:
There were 11 reported outbreaks around the state in the past week, according to the Oregon Health Authority.
People around the state are getting the flu, and hospitalizations have steadily increased since flu season began, with a greater percentage of emergency room visits due to the flu and its symptoms.
This year’s flu season is already worse than three years ago, and trend lines indicate it could be on track with the last two years, which were considered notably bad.
Last year’s flu season caused the most ER visits in the state in recent years but was largely overshadowed by the Northwest’s largest measles outbreak.
There have already been a few measles cases this fall and winter, but the likelihood of getting measles also increases in January and February.

title: Injuries, death, and damage: A weekend traffic violence roundup
summary:
I’ve been following local and regional traffic crashes for a while now and I’m still not numb to the extraordinary impact they have on our city.
On Friday, December 13, 2019 at 7:06p.m., Central Precinct Officers were dispatched to a report of a pedestrian struck by a car near the intersection of Southeast Grand Avenue and Southeast Belmont Street.
When officers arrived they found an adult female with serious injuries.
The driver then swerved up onto the sidewalk at Southeast Morrison Street, striking the pedestrian and the building.
The driver then tried to back up and leave again before passers by yelled at her to stop.

title: Portland City Council votes to extend contract with Rapid Response, camp cleanups to resume
summary:
PORTLAND, Ore. — Portland City Council voted Wednesday to extend a contract with Rapid Response Bioclean, a third-party vendor who is tasked with cleaning up homeless camps throughout Portland.
Rapid Response halted sweeping homeless encampments as of Dec. 30, 2019 and will resume as soon as Wednesday evening.
However, the vote to approve the $4.5 million contract with Rapid Response wasn't without contention.
It was initially delayed in December 2019 over internal debate within city council on whether or not sweeps of homeless camps should be happening in the first place.
Following a camp cleanup, Rapid Response crews are required to transport a homeless individuals' personal property to a storage unit in Southeast Portland, where it can be claimed by its rightful owners.

title: Gospel holiday play Black Nativity sparks joyful and triumphant in Portland
summary:
Black Nativity, a gospel-infused Christmas play featuring a majority African American cast, is up and running at Bethel African Methodist Episcopal Church in Northeast Portland.
The play, now in its fifth consecutive year, is produced by the non-profit PassinArt, a Portland-based African American theater company.
While Black Nativity is performed in a church, “it’s not a church program,” Jerry Foster, PassinArt’s artistic director, said.
People who come enjoy it and feel uplifted.”Backstage before a performance of Langston Hughes' Black Nativity by the non-profit PassinArt.
“That’s where our talent comes from.”Backstage before a performance of Langston Hughes' Black Nativity by the non-profit PassinArt.
